qas.question: How much warmer is Neptune's south pole to the rest of it's atmosphere?
What is the average temperature of Neptune's south pole?
Where does methane in the south pole escape to on Neptune?
How many earth years is Neptune's south pole exposed to the sun?
To which pole will Neptune's methane shift to as it moves to the opposite side of the sun?
How much colder is Neptune's south pole to the rest of it's atmosphere?
What is the average temperature of Neptune's north pole?
Where does methane in the north pole escape to on Neptune?
How many mars years is Neptune's south pole exposed to the sun?
To which pole will Neptune's methane shift to as it moves to the same side of the sun?

context: In 2007, it was discovered that the upper troposphere of Neptune's south pole was about <a0_0><b5_0>10 K<b5_0/><a0_0/> warmer than the rest of its atmosphere, which averages approximately <a1_0><b6_0>73 K (−200 °C).<b6_0/><a1_0/> The temperature differential is enough to let methane, which elsewhere is frozen in the troposphere, escape into <a2_0>the <b7_0>stratosphere near the pole<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> The relative "hot spot" is due to Neptune's axial tilt, which has exposed the south pole to the Sun for the last quarter of Neptune's year, or roughly <a3_0><b8_0>40<b8_0/><a3_0/> Earth years. As Neptune slowly moves towards the opposite side of the Sun, the <b9_0>south<b9_0/> pole will be darkened and the north pole illuminated, causing the methane release to shift to the <a4_0>north pole<a4_0/>.
